stories.text: When commenting on colleague's work, or when arguing constructively, how often do you use "I think" in an attempt to appear less authoritarian/harsh, or conversely, more open minded. How did it work out? What are the pros and cons that you've observed?
stories.title: Ask HN: How often do you use “I think”?

Show HN: A better Yahoo Finance using your own API keys

stories.text:
Every time I install a browser (be it FF or Chrome), I install a set of extensions right off the bat. uBlock Origin is one of them. But I also install extensions that customize my experience on Google, and "detoxify" Google to some extent. For example, I use uBO to filter "People Also Search For" on search results, and I used to use another extension that would let me know when was the last time I visited links on the search page. I also use extensions so that Google doesn't show me results from Medium/Quora/Pinterest.

I think all of this and more could be part of a "sane" search engine that would give the power to the user. I don't use DDG because many of the extensions I mentioned above are not available for it, and also because I simply don't trust them.

Given Mozilla's mission and their success with reviving FF, I wonder if a search engine is on their to-do list in the future.
stories.title: Ask HN: Why doesn't Mozilla launch a search engine?
What's behind the rapid disappearance of the delta variant in Japan
